diagnosis.score_headline: Identity Split: The Specialist vs. The Commodity
diagnosis.score_summary: The brand is suffering from significant strategic drift between its technical website and its populist Amazon listing. While the Core Identity (Archetypes, Positioning) remains intact, the Commercial Execution (USP, Mission, Messaging) has completely fractured, creating two distinct businesses operating under one name.

truth_1.headline: Selling The Method vs. Selling The Fluid
truth_1.gap_description: WWW sells 'The System' (Proprietary Pump/Pack). PDP sells 'The Ingredient' (Golden Oil). You are a med-tech company on your site and a commodity trader on Amazon.
truth_1.evidence: WWW USP: 'The System' (5/5) vs. PDP USP: 'The Ingredient King' (1/5)
truth_1.why_matters: Systems command high margins; commodities command low margins. By leading with the oil on Amazon, you devalue the proprietary technology that justifies your premium price point.
truth_1.the_hard_choice: You are currently competing with your own distinctiveness. If the oil is the hero, your pump is a gimmick. You must decide: either pull the commodity oil forward on the site to drive volume (Option A), or restrict the Amazon listing to 'System-Only' bundles to force the market to value your innovation (Option B). You cannot be a specialist and a generalist simultaneously.

truth_2.headline: The Lab Coat vs. The Shaman
truth_2.gap_description: WWW is 'The Chemist' (Rational/Specs). PDP is 'The Alchemist' (Evocative/Energy). Your website speaks to the brain, but your Amazon page speaks to the soul.
truth_2.why_matters: The disconnection breaks the chain of trust. A customer seduced by 'Energetic Flow' on Amazon arrives at the website and finds a cold spec sheet. The emotional hook is severed.
truth_2.the_hard_choice: You are trying to win on 'Science' locally and 'Vibes' globally. This is unsustainable. You must choose: either purge the spiritual language from Amazon to secure your medical authority (Option A), or update the website to embrace the 'Alchemist' identity and sell the magic of the ritual (Option B). Science validates, but magic converts.

truth_3.headline: The Velvet Rope is Broken
truth_3.gap_description: WWW positions as 'Scientific Vanguard' (High Barriers). PDP positions as 'The Democratizer' (Access for All). You are trying to be an exclusive clinic and a walk-in dispensary at the same time.
truth_3.why_matters: Pricing erosion. The website signals a $37 educational investment. Amazon signals a $20 impulse buy. The lower barrier on the marketplace trains the customer to view your 'Medical Grade' claim as marketing fluff.
truth_3.the_hard_choice: Your pricing architecture is at war with your brand positioning. You face a binary choice: either gate the brand by removing the entry-level SKUs from Amazon to protect the 'Medical' status (Option A), or pivot the entire company to 'Masstige' and win on volume (Option B). You cannot charge a premium for a product you are democratizing.

truth_4.headline: The Polite Bore
truth_4.gap_description: Both channels align perfectly on 'The Gentle Guide' (95% match). The tone is safe, respectful, and helpful. In a crowded wellness market, 'Safe' often means 'Invisible'.
truth_4.evidence: Tone of Voice: 'Gentle Guide' (WWW) matches 'Gentle Guide' (PDP)
truth_4.why_matters: While consistent, the tone lacks the 'Ruler' authority your name implies. You are 'Queen of the Thrones,' but you speak like a dental hygienist. This creates a drag on brand recall.
truth_4.the_hard_choice: Your name writes a check your copy refuses to cash. You are consistent, but you are quiet. The choice is strategic: either maintain this 'Gentle' safety to avoid alienating conservative buyers (Option A), or inject the 'Ruler' archetype into the voice to match your bold name (Option B). Politeness is not a strategy; it is a lack of one.

truth_5.headline: Gold Beats Gray
truth_5.gap_description: WWW relies on 'Clinical Gray' (Quiet Trust). PDP leans into 'Amber & Gold' (Radiating). The Amazon page looks more like a 'Queen' than the brand home.
truth_5.evidence: Visual Thermostat: WWW (3/5 Neutral) vs. PDP (4/5 Warm)
truth_5.why_matters: The Marketplace is executing the brand's 'Royal' promise better than the flagship site. The gold/amber palette triggers a subconscious 'Luxury/Potent' cue that the gray site misses.
truth_5.the_hard_choice: The Amazon team has discovered that warmth sells 'Healing' better than sterility. You have a clear upgrade path: either discipline the Amazon visuals to match the sterile website (Option A), or re-skin the website with the Amazon 'Gold/Amber' palette to own the 'Royal' identity (Option B). Clinical is clean, but Gold is authoritative.

marker_1.so_what: This is a drift in authority. The site says power comes from the 'Soil' (USDA), while Amazon says it comes from the 'Doctor' (Practitioner Grade). You are confusing the customer about who is actually in charge of the quality.

marker_2.so_what: A fatal strategic conflict. The website is building a 'Velvet Rope' around the brand (Education/Price), while Amazon is cutting the rope (Mass Access). You are actively dismantling your own premium positioning.

marker_3.so_what: The one area of absolute lockstep. Both channels agree that 'Purity' is the religion. This obsession with 'Hexane-Free' is the anchor holding the fragmented identity together.

marker_4.so_what: A perfect strategic match. Both channels project the 'Naturopathic Clinic' vibe flawlessly. This proves the brand *can* be consistent, making the other gaps even more inexcusable.

marker_5.so_what: The website is a Lecturer; the Amazon page is a Therapist. The website maintains professional distance, while Amazon gets intimate and affectionate. This inconsistency dilutes the brand's perceived seniority.

marker_6.so_what: The 'Queen' identity is structurally sound across channels. The 'Ruler/Sage' combination is the brand's strongest asset, providing a consistent feeling of 'Control' in a chaotic wellness market.

marker_7.so_what: The voice is disciplined but dangerously safe. It is consistent, but it is 'Beige.' In a market screaming for attention, being this polite is a risk disguised as a virtue.

marker_8.so_what: The layout physics match, but the temperature is different. Amazon's use of 'Gold/Amber' feels more premium and 'Royal' than the website's clinical 'Gray.' The marketplace is actually upgrading the visual promise.

marker_9.so_what: A bait and switch. The website argues with facts ('Cold-Pressed'), while Amazon seduces with magic ('Energetic Flow'). You are attracting two different customers who will likely dislike the other channel's experience.

marker_10.so_what: The hero of the story changes. On the site, the 'Farm' is the hero. On Amazon, the 'Doctor' is the hero. This narrative drift confuses the source of the product's power.

marker_11.so_what: Solid alignment on the 'Checklist' strategy (Hexane-Free, Non-GMO). The minor drift is just in *who* validates it (Logos vs. Doctor), but the core promise of 'Safety' is secure.

marker_12.so_what: The single biggest commercial break. The website sells a high-margin 'System' (Pump/Pack), while Amazon sells a low-margin commodity (Oil). You are cannibalizing your own innovation by training the customer to just buy the liquid.

marker_13.so_what: Both channels treat the customer as a student. The content strategy is consistently educational, prioritizing 'Why it works' over lifestyle fluff. This builds deep, long-term trust.

marker_14.so_what: The website promises a Cure (Internal Cleansing/Healing). Amazon promises a Look (Shiny Hair/Dewy Skin). You are selling medicine on one channel and makeup on the other.

marker_15.so_what: Both channels tap into the same deep emotional vein: Fear of Toxins. The promise of 'Sanctuary' (safety in one's body) is the strongest emotional hook the brand has, and it is executed consistently.

marker_16.so_what: The user identity is stable ('I am a Purist'). The drift is only in motivation: Website users buy for 'Taste' (Statement), while Amazon users buy for 'Logic' (Smart Choice). This is an acceptable variance.

marker_17.so_what: Both channels successfully leverage the user's desire to feel 'Superior' to the toxic mainstream. The brand effectively creates an 'Us vs. Them' dynamic (Clean vs. Chemical) that drives loyalty.
